cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure and Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness and High Temperature Corrosion are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

remarks: Relation mainly encodes co-membership in the same list; not implying any causal or structural dependency between the mechanisms.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: High Temperature Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: both are subsections under the same damage mechanisms section

remarks: Relation created to capture that both mechanisms are co-classified in the same document section; direction is arbitrary.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two concepts are presented as peer categories or sections within the same classification or list (e.g., in a document), without implying causal, hierarchical, or structural dependency.
args.justification: All three relations describe damage mechanism categories that are presented as peer sections within the same document list/section. The semantics are symmetric co-membership in a classification structure, not causality or hierarchy. A normalized predicate 'co_classified_with' better captures this document-structure-based association than the raw label and can be reused consistently.
args.remark: Direction is arbitrary; the predicate should be interpreted as symmetric.

args.justification: Each relation instance encodes that two damage mechanisms are co-listed or co-sectioned in the same document classification (peer sections in a list of mechanisms). This is best modeled as a document-level co-classification family rather than causal, compositional, or hierarchical relations.

The relations express that entities are associated by being co-members of the same document-defined list or section, not that they are identical, causal, temporal, or spatially related. This fits a broad ASSOCIATION group.

The semantics are symmetric co-membership in a classification structure, not causality or hierarchy. A normalized predicate 'co_classified_with' better captures this document-structure-based association than the raw label and can be reused consistently.
executed_decisions.remark: Direction is arbitrary; the predicate should be interpreted as symmetric.

executed_decisions.justification: Each relation instance encodes that two damage mechanisms are co-listed or co-sectioned in the same document classification (peer sections in a list of mechanisms). This is best modeled as a document-level co-classification family rather than causal, compositional, or hierarchical relations.

The relations express that entities are associated by being co-members of the same document-defined list or section, not that they are identical, causal, temporal, or spatially related. This fits a broad ASSOCIATION group.
